column2: I'd like a database to keep track of my moods
column3: as a user i’d like a database to keep track of my lists and moods so that i can see them when i return to the site.
column14: This database is small but will keep track of some very important information. Although we will be getting some tasks from API or Just some that the user has specified we will still need to know if the user has checked these off. In the database we will keep the list in a table. The first column will hold the calendar ID, the second column being the eventID from the API. The third column will be if its been checked off or not in a boolean variable. True will be that it is checked off and false will mean it is not checked off. Each user will link to this table with a foreign key from the list table. This will allow us to pull up a user’s check list and display it. The database will start with our pre-made logins and password table. This will link to the list in a foreign key. The list will hold there google calendar logins. Then that will link to a task with a forign key. This is how the tables will related to each or for the google API and list/To-Do list portion. There may be some research in this to make sure this is an effective way to make our database. Talking to someone with more database knowledge might make this a more effective database. I can send an email to someone I know to see what their thoughts are on this as well as talking to Scott about what he thinks.

column19: Talk to Group about anything else we need to add

column2: I'd like to have the ability to sign up or login to my google account so that I can use the website to its full ability
column3: as a user i want to be able to login with google account information to the website so that i can access my personal information.
column14: The core features of the website rely heavily on the google calendar API. Keeping this in mind, a requirement of using most of the features of the website will be having a google account. When someone initially visits the website there will be a welcome page and only two buttons login or register. If you already have a google account you can simply login and be on your way to tracking your mood and doing self care. If you don’t have one yet you will be able to sign up. This feature will require acquiring a client ID and client secret from google developer site and using that to make our site have the ability to login or sign up via google. We will need to first agree to make a shared google account for all of us to sign up and access google API information. Then we can sign up as a google developer after agreeing to terms and conditions. From here we can make a project name and give the URL for our Azure website. After everything is connected we can clock the Oauth link to obtain the ID and secret needed to continue. We then use these in our web application to be able to connect a google account to the site. There will not be a register page since it will link to google.com and if they don't have an account they will be able to register from there.  There will not be a captcha that we have designed since google will be taking care of the accounts.
column17: Create a shared google account for our web application
column19: Research how to set up logging in via google on an ASP.NET application
column21: Sign up to access API info using the email created
column23: Obtain the client ID and secret from google needed to set up the ability to login/signup through google
column25: Setup the code with the obtained tokens
column27: Adjust the views to have a button to login via google
column29: Test if you are able to login via google

column2: As a user, I'd like to see a clean welcome page so that I can get an idea of what the site is about
column3: as a user i'd like a cohesive modern website that is easy to navigate so that i am encouraged to keep using it and don't get frustrated with messy text and links
column14: A welcome page is incredibly important because first impressions are key when wanting to attract users to a site. We want users to get the impression that this is a positive space for anyone, no matter who they are. By doing this, we will encourage users to sign up and explore all the wonderful options and features we will provide to them. Color is key here when we are talking about attracting users, we want the color scheme to be modern and simple yet eye catching and intriguing. Also, our goal, as with any welcome page, is to inform the visitor of what our site is all about as well as the features that they offer. We aim to attract everyone and anyone who wants assistance in keeping track of their day to day tasks, keeping track of their moods and trends in their moods over time, and really anyone who wants to improve their overall well being. Also on our welcome page, there will be a bottom section with quick links to terms of service, an about us page, and other links that visitors might find useful upon coming to our website for the first time. Additionally, the welcome page will really be a tell of the structure and theme of the website. Personally, if there is a website I visit that has poor theme and structure, I find that I don’t use it or don’t choose to use its features. A good welcome page is our way of making a first impression with our lovely users!
column17: Decide on a theme for the site
column19: decide on a color scheme for the site
column25: add mock terms of service page

column2: As a user, I'd like to see a clean log-in and sign-up page so that it is easy for me to get into my account as well as create an account.
column3: as a user i'd like a cohesive modern website that is easy to navigate so that i am encouraged to keep using it and don't get frustrated with messy text and links
column14: Many times when you visit a website, you are prompted with a welcome page and a sign up right next to it. If you are an existing user, it can sometimes be way too difficult to even locate the button that says "sign in" or "log in". This will be different for our site. The goal here is to be very clear on where to sign in to your existing account, and to be very clear on what criteria is needed to sign up for an account. As far as being clear on the criteria needed to sign up goes, this means that ones you fill in all the boxes such as email and password, we will not direct the user to a separate page where we require more information such as a username and a full name. This will make the entire sign up process very streamlined and easy to use, as well as encourage visitors to sign up with us! Additionally, being able to locate the log in button easily will avoid a lot of frustrations from our existing users, and will also encourage them to continue using our site. Our goal is to make things as clear cut and easy to read as possible in order to encourage user and visitor satisfaction!
column17: Create very nice looking log in and sign up buttons
column19: format the site to cater to full sign up requirements without it taking up too much space/being obnoxious
column23: create an easy to see spot for log in button

column2: As a user I'd like a clean cut user interface so that I don't have to scroll through a disorganized mess of links and resources
column3: as a user i’d like to be able to be shown a list of mental health resources that i may not be aware of such as text lines suicide hotline numbers and venting hotline numbers.
column14: Messy links that are hard to read are a huge problem for many websites. Some sites simply put links without editing their link to say something else, and just put the raw http link. This makes it near impossible for users to read and see where the link is taking them, and that is a huge issue for user interface. In our site, we want to make sure that this problem is avoided by giving all of our links appropriate names so that we can avoid any user confusion. Additionally, we want to avoid just a simple bullet point list of all of the amazing resources we can show the user. We would like to create a creative way to show the user different links and resources that is easy to read and understand, because scrolling through a whole list of bullet points with thinks you cant understand make you not want to even attempt to read and utilize the links. This could implement a lot of different things such as rounded boxes with links inside or other interesting shapes with the links inside. This page also needs to be created to begin with, and remain as consistent as possible with the rest of the website. The overall goal is to create a user interface that does not frustrate the user and make them want to leave our website and never use it again.
column19: create links inside resources page to therapist locator API and other pieces of our resources feature

column2: As a user, I'd like to be shown relevant and current links to resources so that I do not attempt to use broken links and outdated information.
column3: as a user i’d like to be able to be shown a list of mental health resources that i may not be aware of such as text lines suicide hotline numbers and venting hotline numbers.
column14: Being directed to an outdated link when it comes to mental health resources can be not only frustrating but also harmful. Also, a link to a broken site or a broken link in general is very bad for the user experience in general. These links to resources can be a variety of things, such as current news on mental health research, links to websites such as To Write Love On Her Arms, and many other resources that pertain to mental health, self care, and overall well-being. Creating this list will take a bit of careful research and collaboration with team members in order to cultivate a useful and relevant collection of links. We do not want to be linking to anything that is not relevant to mental health or self care, and we especially do not want to link to anything that a user would take as diagnostic. Teaming up with my team members will really be helpful in getting different perspectives on what we should and should not be including on this resources page. Our purpose is to provide positive resources that are genuinely useful and informative to our users. We also would like to, down the road, continue to add and update resources so that way we truly stay on top of current trends and information.
column19: Collaborate with team in order to ensure we are on the same page with resources
column21: add them in an order that makes sense

column2: As a user I would like to see my google calandar events
column3: as a user i want to be able to login with google account information to the website so that i can access my personal information.
column14: One of the cool things of this application is to stay organized. With this, we need a way to keep track of the things going on in our busy lives as well as things to take care of ourselves on a daily basis. The approach we are going to take is using a google account as the primary way to use this application. Once you have registered for this account, your google calendar will connected to the application. After this user story a registered user will be able to view the events on their calendar. This will require learning how to set up google calendar api with an ASP.net web application. The first thing we need to do is create a new cloud platform application, this will generate a client ID that we will use to connect our web application. Next, in order to begin using it will be installing Install-Package Google.Apis.Calendar.v3. Lastly, we will just have to write the code that will display all the events. Then we will test this to see if it works.  Since the google API will be connected after this story, this will make it easier in the future stories where we will be using google calendar in our application.  A user will eventually be able to add a list of events that we recommend for self care. They will also be able to add custom events that they want, as well as medication notifications. So this will help them remember to work on themselves as well as everything else.
column17: create a new cloud platform application, this will generate a client ID to connect our app

column2: I'd like a database to keep levels of to do lists
column3: as a user i’d like to be able to pick from different levels of to do lists or customize a to do list so that i can easily accomplish tasks that range from basic to complex.
column14: This database will keep the level of to do lists and will keep what has been done or checked off. This will be there so users can pick and choose what level of to do lists they want to do today. An example would be like level one would be get up, take meds, and drink water. A level two would add on to those and have take a shower, make food, and brush teeth. This table would just have those in there only. This would be so that users can take those and put them into their own to do lists. There will be another table which would have the users to do list. Users will be able to add to this list from the other table and their own google calendar. This table will have a foreign key from the user login table and then they will have their events and to do lists. To this table there will also be a boolean variable that will have if the user has checked off the list or not. This will be there so we can keep track if the user has checked off someone as done or not. Having this in the database will keep it even if the user refreshes the page. Now the user can look at there to do list at any time and see what there is to do and what they need to do. It will be easy to get the users key and search the table to get their information.

column2: In order to better take care of myself, I would like a list of tasks that I might be able to do to better practice self care.
column3: as a user i'd like a guide on how to properly take care of myself.
column14: Self care can be a confusing concept for many. Some thing that self care is just doing a face mask, taking a bubble bath, or eating a piece of cake. While these can be methods of self care, people can think that these are really the ONLY ways to practice self care. Instead I will compile a curated list of things that someone can do to give someone a good jumping off point.

column2: Sometimes I'm feeling too lazy to read through an entire check list. I'd like to just click through a flow chart.
column3: as a user i'd like a guide on how to properly take care of myself.
column14: In order to help users figure out the proper way to take care of themselves, this interactive flowchart will help users help them figure out what they need at that moment to help them boost their mood and trigger a release of dopamine/serotonin. The flowchart will implement a logic trail similar to that of Maslow’s hierarchy of needs so that users can follow a logical trail from more immediate needs that are quick and easy to satisfy, like a snack or a cup of tea, to much more complex ones, like to perhaps throw some paint on a canvas or phone a friend. This will be a tool that someone could use from the homepage in the final product. The user will not need to be logged into use this. Logged in users may have the option to add activities from flow chart into custom task list in the future. The final product will rely heavily on AJAX so that users are not stuck waiting for something to load and should feel seamless and to make it so the page need not refresh between clicks. However, the bulk of the logic will be implemented in C# and so the first implementation of this will be clicking text boxes to help users end up at a suggestion for how to boost their mood. The text boxes should have pleasant non-busy shapes and muted colors that are easy on the eyes. Clicking one option should make the next logical text prompt appear.
column17: Research most logical way to implement flowchart that doesn’t require my teammates to download shoddy packages
column19: Set up logic from hierarchy chart found at https://www.nami.org/getattachment/Extranet/Education,-Training-and-Outreach-Programs/Signature-Classes/NAMI-Homefront/HF-Additional-Resources/HF15AR6SelfCare.pdf
column21: Implement visual representation of this flowchart by having users start from the top and work their way down
column23: Let users follow a logical flow chart from one action to the next. The flow will be much like a "choose your own adventure"  feel where different choices bring different outcomes
column25: I would like the design of the flow cart to match the overall layout of the site.
